Award.AwardTitle: High-resolution seismic models of the upper mantle beneath the Indian Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study addresses the relationship between the physical structure of tectonic plates and the chemistry and partial melting processes of the underlying mantle, from which magma that forms new plates is generated. Past studies have focused on the fast-spreading Pacific but plates formed at slower spreading rate and lower magma supply may have different structure and different types of chemical variability. Analysis of data covering the slow-spreading Indian Ocean basin will provide the first seismic and geochemical results at a resolution similar to that available for the Pacific. Comparison will distinguish characteristics that are global features of plate aging versus regional features reflecting a particular basin's magmatic development.

Regional models of upper mantle seismic velocity, attenuation, and radial anisotropy beneath the Indian Ocean will be developed. Both the average age-dependent seismic structure and deviations from the average will be determined. Only earthquakes and seismic stations located within or on the margins of the Indian Ocean will be used, to avoid paths with significant length through continental upper mantle. Frequency-dependent phase and amplitude of fundamental-mode and higher-mode surface waves will be measured and jointly inverted for elastic and anelastic seismic models. This approach takes advantage of the amplitude sensitivity to short wavelength structure to allow estimation of attenuation and shear velocity in a self-consistent manner. Mantle temperature, partial-melt content, and composition of the upper mantle will be estimated by interpreting the seismic models together with existing mineral physics, mid-ocean-ridge basalt composition, and bathymetry data. The research will be the basis of a PhD thesis and undergraduates will also be involved in aspects of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plate tectonics is expressed most simply in ocean basins. Ocean basins record the life history of a tectonic plate—its creation at a mid-ocean ridge, its thickening over time, and its consumption at a subduction zone. The movement of tectonic plates is possible because the lithosphere, Earth’s stiff outermost shell, slides on top of a weak asthenosphere that exists beneath it. However, despite its fundamental role in facilitating plate tectonics, the nature of the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary is poorly understood. Outstanding questions remain about the physical and chemical properties of rocks that allow the lithosphere to be stiff and rigid while the asthenosphere is weak and flows easily.  The issue is further complicated by the fact that our understanding of the lithosphere and asthenosphere beneath ocean basins is dominated by studies of the Pacific basin. Much less is known about the lithosphere and asthenosphere beneath the other ocean basins.

 

Our study was focused on the speed of earthquake-generated seismic waves as they traveled through the lithosphere and asthenosphere beneath the Indian Ocean. With measurements of wave speed, seismologists can estimate the temperature of the rocks in Earth’s deep interior. These measurements can also tell us about the chemical composition of the rocks, whether the rocks are partially molten, and if there are reservoirs of water and carbon dioxide deep inside the Earth. Our results showed that seismic-wave speeds within the lithosphere of the Indian Ocean depend on the age of the seafloor: waves travel faster beneath older seafloor and slower beneath young seafloor, especially beneath the mid-ocean ridge. The change of seismic-wave speed with age indicates that the lithosphere is growing colder and thicker over time as heat is lost through conduction.

 

Within the Indian Ocean, we did not find evidence that the lithosphere achieves a maximum thickness; instead, it continues to grow thicker with age. However, we also performed an analysis of lithosphere thickness in the Atlantic and Pacific basins, and the results were quite different. In the Pacific, when the seafloor is around 70-80 million years old, the lithosphere stops growing thicker, at least for 10-20 million years. In the Atlantic, the behavior of the lithosphere is much more variable. In some areas it continues to grow thicker indefinitely and in other areas it achieves a maximum thickness, similar to what happens in the Pacific.

 

Taken together, these results show that the oceanic lithosphere is stiff because it is both cold and dehydrated relative to the warm and damp asthenosphere that underlies it. Due to conductive cooling, the thickness of the cold layer increases with time. However, the thickness of the dehydrated layer does not change with time. Since cold rocks are not only stiff but also dense, we hypothesize that when the cold layer grows thicker than the dehydrated layer, some of bottom of the lithosphere detaches and sinks into the asthenosphere. This has the effect of thinning, and therefore limiting the thickness of, the lithosphere. If the dehydrated layer is thin, this would happen at a relatively young age. If the dehydrated layer is thick, this would be prevented from happening.  Since the thickness of oceanic lithosphere controls the volume of the ocean basins, our result provides a mechanism to change the storage capacity of ocean basins over time.
